subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: Don t worry about the Australians. My suggestion is to go through the lexical set exercise using your Boston accent. Then stick to the results. I ll be more
messageBody:
Don't worry about the Australians. My suggestion is to go through the
lexical set exercise using your Boston accent. Then stick to the
results. I'll be more comfortable reading your news knowing that I'm
reading an authentic Boston accent than wondering which dictionary you
used for each word.

If you want a different accent, recruit a native speaker to represent
it. For example, I'd be happy to give you a mapping of the CMU
phonemes for the US West Coast accent. And I'd be happy to serve as a
curator to catch errors and extend the dictionary. My hunch is that we
can get by with the CMU dictionary for nearly all American accents,
but that we'll need a different one for the British Isles.

I wouldn't presume to speak for John Cowan. It seems to me that
Kingsley Read was trying to come as close *as possible* to a universal
system for the major dialects of English. As the example of the BATH
lexical set shows, perfection is not possible.

Ted


On Nov 13, 2007 4:23 PM, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> >
> >
> > I think the upshot of the lexical set discussion is that if used
> > intelligently, it can *greatly reduce* the differences between QS
> > written by people who speak with different accents. It will not
> > *eliminate* the differences. Look again at John Cowan's message (Nov.
> > 6):
> > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/message/1353
> > <http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/message/1353>
> >
> > Under "Group III" he says,
> >
> > "Either BATH is like TRAP or BATH is like PALM; in the former case you
> > write BATH words with At, the same vowel as TRAP words; in the latter
> > case, with Ah, the same vowel as PALM words."
>
> I thought the major difference would be with words like "bath." But with
> Australians, it might be some other set. So I can get used to seeing
> words like "bath" spelled differently, but then do I have to get use to
> another set for Australians?
>
>
> >
> > So an English and American QS scribe will write BATH words
> > differently. And that's OK. We already have different spellings, but
> > if I pick up a London newspaper I can read it as easily as I read the
> > New York Times.
>
> But the difference in spelling between British and American English is
> almost non-existent. I am guessing that one could read an entire article
> and not come across a difference. In contrast, one could come across a
> different spelling between a British and American scribe in QS nearly
> every sentence. That could slow down your reading.
>
>
> >
> > In my view, here's the program: you go through the lexical sets, using
> > Anthony's charts or some web interface with check boxes or whatever
> > and you end up with a guide to using QS for your particular accent.
> > Then you stick to your own accent. Don't try to guess someone else's
> > accent. The user-testing that was done 40 years ago showed that this
> > system will allow effective communication across the major accents in
> > the English-speaking world.
> >
> > QS has the expressive power to capture different accents, and that is
> > a strength, not a weakness. Let's use it.
> >
>
> John Cowan, though, has argued just the opposite, that QS really can't
> represent accents (there really aren't any letters for many of the
> Australian vowels, for example), and even if it could, we wouldn't want
> to read text in a dialect completely different than our own because it
> would take us literally at least 3 times longer to do so. In a book I
> read several years ago called *Writing Systems," the author points out
> that Chinese is an effective writing system because it does not try to
> imitate speech. Written Chinese can distinguish between the huge number
> of hononyms that the spoken language cannot. So writing is artificial,
> and QS is artificial in that it dictates we always use "r's" even for we
> non-rhotic speakers, a very wise rule that Read devised. Just think how
> much more difficult QS would be to read if we didn't always have to
> write our r's.
>
> More practically in my case, I need to know what letter to use in words
> like "Pot" so that readers from all over the world can read the news
> relatively easy. Using my Boston accent as a guide seems unwise. On the
> other hand, you are claiming that an experiment conducted 40 years ago
> shows that using your accent as a guide does work. I will have to take
> this on faith. I am not fluent enough in QS to really judge these matters.
>
> Though I sound like I'm trying to argue a completely different way of
> using QS than you, really I'm just trying to get it straight in my own
> head.
>
> Paul
>
>

Don't worry about the Australians. My suggestion is to go through the
lexical set exercise using your Boston accent. Then stick to the
results. I'll be more comfortable reading your news knowing that I'm
reading an authentic Boston accent than wondering which dictionary you
used for each word.

If you want a different accent, recruit a native speaker to represent

I wouldn't presume to speak for John Cowan. It seems to me that

lexical set shows, perfection is not possible.

Ted
